div.p: >> Hi, this is Joyce Farrell.
Let's examine looping.

Suppose you want to write
a program that outputs

hello four times and
then outputs goodbye.

This is the perfect
place to use a loop.

You can start the program and
declare a loop control variable.

We'll call this one "count,"
and we'll initialize it to zero.

Then you compare the loop
control variable to some value.
Count is less than four.

That's true, because
count is zero,

so you enter the loop
body, output hello,
and then add one to count.

Within a loop body, you
always must alter the loop
control variable.
So here, count becomes one.
Is count still less than four?
Yes, it is,

so you output hello a second
time, and then count becomes two.

You compare count to four
again; it's still less,

so you output hello,
and count becomes three.

You compare count to
four; it's still less,

so you output hello,
and count becomes four.

This time when you compare count
to four, it's no longer less.
You don't enter the loop again.

You output goodbye, and
you stop the program.

When you use a loop control
variable in a program,

you must do three
things with it.

You must initialize the
loop control variable.

In this case, we're setting
the loop control variable equal
to zero.

Initializing it doesn't have
to happen when it's declared,

but it has to happen
before the loop body starts.

And initializing doesn't mean
it has to be set to zero.

The loop control variable just
has to be set to some value.

In every loop, the loop
control variable is tested.

In this case, we're testing,
is count less than four.
And in the body of every loop,

the loop control
variable must be altered.

In this case, we're altering
count by adding one to it.
You don't have to add one.

In other loops, you might
add two, or five, or ten.

Other loops, you might
perform subtraction,

and still other loops, you
might change the value of count
by getting user input.

But in some way, the variable
must be altered somewhere
within the loop.

Let's look at a loop in which
the loop control variable was
not initialized.

In this case, the program
starts and count is declared,
but not given an initial value.
When you compare count to four,

one of several things
might happen depending

on the programming
language you're using.

Some languages won't
compile the program,

and count will not be
allowed to be compared to four
until it's given a value.

In other programming languages,
count might just have garbage

in it, and it might be greater
than four or less than four,

and you can't predict which
way the logic will travel
after this question.

In any event, not initializing
the count variable is a mistake.

It's also a mistake to
not test the loop control
variable correctly.

In this program, we wanted to
make sure that count was less

than four, but what if
,by mistake, we said
is count equal to four.

In that case, when the count
was zero, it would not be equal

to four right away, and the
program would output goodbye
and never output hello.

Or by mistake, you might have
typed, count less than 44,

instead of just four, and
you'd get 44 hellos instead

of only the four
that you wanted.

In any event, if you don't
compare the loop control

variable correctly when
you start the program,

and initialize count, you
don't know what the answer

to this question will be or
it'll be an incorrect answer,

and you won't get the
program that you wanted.
Finally, it's also a mistake not

to correctly alter the
loop control variable.
You might make a mistake

by adding too much
or adding too little.

In this case, the programmer
just forgot to type plus one,

so count remains equal to
itself and never increases.

When this program
starts, count is zero.
Is it less than four?
Yes, it's zero,

so you output hello,
and count remains zero.
Is it still less than four?

Well, yes it is, so you output
hello, and count remains zero.
Is it still less than four?

Yes, it's going to be
less than four forever.

You have an infinite loop
and an incorrect program.

In any good loop, you must
initialize the loop control

variable, make sure you're
making the correct test

to start the loop, and
somewhere within the loop,

you have to alter the loop
control variable correctly.
Thanks for watching.
